Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother: “Can you call me? I really need to talk.” I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until my next telemarketing shift. He never asked for help unless it was serious. As his sister, I was supposed to be there, especially when he was struggling. But as I logged into the call system, my supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Stay focused, stick to the script, and don’t let personal matters interfere.” 

The first call came in. The customer fired off technical questions about our new service, questions my script barely covered. I tried to sound confident, but my mind kept drifting to my brother. Was he okay? Was he in trouble? I felt the pressure to handle the customer’s objections smoothly, to keep my numbers up, but my heart was pounding for a different reason. I was torn—my brother needed me, but so did my job. The phone rang again, and I stared at the screen, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I could let down.
